newsitem.title: USA: COMEX copper ends touch lower ahead of holiday.
newsitem.headline: COMEX copper ends touch lower ahead of holiday.

text.p: COMEX copper settled slightly weaker Friday, ending a week of strong gains from three straight sessions of fresh life-of-contract highs in most-active July contract amid dwindling stocks, dealers said.
Copper prices are now at their best since just before the Sumitomo scandal broke last June.
July COMEX copper settled 0.20 cent weaker at 118.75 cents a lb, traded 119.25 to 117.70 cents. Spot May went out 0.75 cent lower at 118.55 cents, ending in contango to July.
"The outlook is quite constructive but we continue to hit resistance as we get close to 120.00 cents," Bette Raptopoulos said. "Perhaps we will get a little pullback before resuming upside momentum."
LME cash to three months premium or backwardation, slipped a touch to about $75/$80 by COMEX close.
July COMEX is now inside overbought territory, according to some dealers, with the 9-day RSI at 82 percent and 14-day RSI at 75 percent.
July, in parallel with LME three months, has surged in the past two weeks, the former ending 7.15 cents higher over this period.
A further draw in LME stocks Friday, down 1,325 tonnes to 137,675 tonnes, helped to underpin the market, dealers said.
Friday's session was quiet, ending an hour early at 1300 EDT ahead of the Memorial Day holiday weekend, with the exchange closed Monday.
LME will also be shut Monday due to a U.K. public holiday.
